BRS is always based on age of 55  not time of withdrawal

I donâ€™t think (I may be wrong)  that if you already topped up RA to ERS at 55  you can then withdraw the difference in ERS vs BRS in full later.The principle of hitting ERS means youâ€™ll need to manually transfer from FRS to ERS at RA. That transferred amount will be reserved and paid out via CPF Life. You can still pledge property to withdraw difference between FRS & BRS but the difference between ERS & FRS is reserved.

And he answered you. BRS and FRS is locked at 55. Even if you hit FRS  there's absolutely no way you can hit ERS through mandatory contributions with the existing CPF annual contributions limit.Read the related FAQs available:https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/withdrawing-for-immediate-retirement-needs/withdrawal-of-cpf-savings-for-property-ownershttps://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/once-i-meet-my-full-retirement-sum--my-special-account-savings-w

Refunds will be counted on the statement month that you're currently on. If you don't spend in Feb  your refund in Feb for a Jan's transaction will be counted in Feb and brings the current spending to negative.

Hi  I have negative credit card balance in my OCBC account due to a refund. Can I withdraw that balance? Would it effect my credit score and be treated as cash advance? Would refund from another card lead to miles cashback? Thanks inadvance
Do you mean credit card  rather than account? (negative on bank account usually means you withdrew more money than you have  which is a bad sign)

1. Refund would probably trigger a points clawback2. Negative on your card in this case means thereâ€™s money put into the card  not the other way around. So no concerns about being treated as cash advance or similar3. Personally I would just continue spending on that card as per normal to draw down on that surplus  might be more troublesome to try and transfer/withdraw it out
